Plus, some of their systems are ancient and hard to support

Use Case:
The ICT Strategy is built on three main ideas:
Better support for clinicians and patient care.
Aligning with big NSW Health plans.
Saving a lot of money.

These ideas guide five key objectives:
Using ICT to drive big changes in clinical care.
Cutting down on duplicated admin systems and costs.
Providing top-notch info to everyone in the organization.
Setting up a flexible ICT system that supports both clinical and corporate reforms.
Managing ICT in a smart, coordinated way to get the most out of the investment.

Use Case:
From the RSP:
They've picked out results and services that rely on ICT assets.
They've identified risks related to ICT assets that could affect service delivery.
They've pinpointed services and measures that hinge on ICT assets working properly.

From the NSW Health Corporate Plan:
They've considered the overall vision for the community.
They've outlined how NSW Health will contribute to this vision.
They've focused on strategies to achieve goals, along with potential risks.
They've set up ways to measure performance and ensure targets are met.
They've looked at the costs involved in reaching the vision and meeting targets.

    Adherence to state ICT strategic planning requirements.
    Potential to generate a positive return on investment.

Use Case:
The RSP is NSW Health's main plan to tackle challenges. They have four main goals:
Keep people healthy
Provide needed healthcare
Deliver top-quality services
Manage health services well

To achieve these, they focus on seven key directions:
Get everyone involved in prevention
Improve people's healthcare experiences
Strengthen community care
Work with others for better health
Make wise choices about healthcare costs
Build a strong healthcare workforce
Stay prepared for new challenges and chances

Use Case: The NSW Government is changing how they use computers and stuff. They want to save money on the boring tech stuff while keeping important services running smoothly. They're spending more on technology for important services and finding ways to save money with computers. This means using one fund for all tech needs, having a plan for the whole state, using fewer computer programs, sharing tech, and buying things together.

Use Case: The eHealth initiative involves all states, territories, and the Australian Government. It began in 2000 to set up e-health across Australia. The Australian Government has invested $128 million in e-health projects across the country, plus an extra $10 million in 2005 for managed health network grants. The aim is to make sure everyone works together, with consistent approaches to eHealth, creating a national health information network. The program also helps make the right rules for eHealth initiatives.

Plus, they're making sure the stuff doctors send each other is safe, and helping with buying healthcare stuff

Use Case: In the Implementation phase, they're putting in the content decided by the state. Doing it all at once might seem like a lot, but it's the most efficient and cost-effective way. Using the Fast Track Method makes things quicker and cheaper, sticking to a standard design with state content. This means less hassle and less time spent learning for Area Health Services staff. Their team knows how to build the database, and doing things fast helps them stick to the plan without adding extra stuff.
